page.title: 12History of C M beach
page.content: The river Umber flows into the sea at one side of the beach. Before piped water was available, the houses at Seaside drew water from the river via the steps which are still there although there is no access to the beach from them. Prior to 1914 all incoming and outgoing goods were carried by sea. Strawberry growing used to be a major industry and the bulk of the crop went by boat across the Bristol Channel to Swansea. Coal was brought back and unloaded on the beach into horse drawn carts. The main Harbour Beach used to be privately owned but was recently bought by the Parish Council. Newberry Beach is still privately owned. "Saltdene" the only remaining thatched cottage in the village is on the cliffs at the side of Newberry Beach.
